issue.title: feat: support async formatter

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: This change enhances an existing feature of ESLint

labels.name: core
labels.description: Relates to ESLint's core APIs and features

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: There is consensus among the team that this change meets the criteria for inclusion

labels.name: archived due to age
labels.description: This issue has been archived; please open a new issue for any further discussion

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

issue.body:
closes #15242

<!--
    Thank you for contributing!

    ESLint adheres to the [JS Foundation Code of Conduct](https://js.foundation/community/code-of-conduct).
-->

#### Prerequisites checklist

- [x] I have read the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/eslint/eslint/blob/HEAD/CONTRIBUTING.md).

#### What is the purpose of this pull request? (put an "X" next to an item)

<!--
    The following template is intentionally not a markdown checkbox list for the reasons
    explained in https://github.com/eslint/eslint/pull/12848#issuecomment-580302888
-->

[ ] Documentation update
[ ] Bug fix ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/bug-report.md))
[ ] New rule ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/rule-proposal.md))
[ ] Changes an existing rule ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/HEAD/templates/rule-change-proposal.md))
[ ] Add autofixing to a rule
[ ] Add a CLI option
[x] Add something to the core: support async formatter
[ ] Other, please explain

<!--
    If the item you've checked above has a template, please paste the template questions below and answer them. (If this pull request is addressing an issue, you can just paste a link to the issue here instead.)
-->

<!--
    Please ensure your pull request is ready:

    - Read the pull request guide (https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/pull-requests)
    - Include tests for this change
    - Update documentation for this change (if appropriate)
-->

<!--
    The following is required for all pull requests:
-->

#### What changes did you make? (Give an overview)

Added `await` ahead of `formatter.format`

#### Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?

body: Seems like an easy enough change now that most CLI methods are async. I’m in favor. Let’s see what the team thinks.

No objections from me, but should we treat this as a semver-minor or semver-major change? It can be argued that this changes the interface of [`eslint.loadFormatter`](https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/nodejs-api#-eslintloadformatternameorpath) because it changes its return type ([Formatter](https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/nodejs-api#-formatter-type)).
I think semver-minor, as it doesn’t affect the ability to use existing formatters and doesn’t require any users to do anything differently.

It certainly doesn't affect anything that can be done now, but integrations that use `eslint.loadFormatter()` might be seen as incompatible after this change. For example, `eslint-webpack-plugin` allows users to define `formatter` field in the configuration and loads them with `eslint.loadFormatter()`. We release this in ESLint v8.2.0, and there's a published async formatter. `eslint-webpack-plugin` didn't expect async formatters, so it becomes in a certain way incompatible with ESLint v8.2.0 because it doesn't work with v8.2.0-compatible formatters.

That still doesn’t seem like a semver-major issue to me. eslint.loadFormatter() doesn’t guarantee the signature of the module it is loading. you could pass in any random file and only when you go to call the function will you know if it works (or if, for example, the module returned an object instead of a function)

> That still doesn’t seem like a semver-major issue to me. eslint.loadFormatter() doesn’t guarantee the signature of the module it is loading. you could pass in any random file and only when you go to call the function will you know if it works (or if, for example, the module returned an object instead of a function)

That's true, we cannot really verify and guarantee the signature of the loaded function, and user can always specify a module that isn't actually an ESLint formatter. But, that's then an invalid formatter, and thus user's fault.

A difference here is that integrations will be getting _valid_ ESLint formatters with unexpected signatures, which is a kind of compatibility issue. I don't have a very strong opinion on this, though. If you don't think this is a breaking change for integrations, I'll agree.

I think we can mitigate some of the issues by recommending that integrators always “await” the formatter call so it can work either way.

@btmills can you chime in as well?
If there is an ESLint integration list, I can help send PRs to these repositories to add `await`

@fengzilong we don’t have an integrations list, which is part of the challenge here.

It sounds like we now have agreement that this change doesn’t have to wait for a major release, so we can proceed.

> It sounds like we now have agreement that this change doesn’t have to wait for a major release, so we can proceed.

That's great that it can be released soon 🎉

issue.title: feat(utils): update eslint types

repository.name: typescript-eslint
repository.description: :sparkles: Monorepo for all the tooling which enables ESLint to support TypeScript

issue.body:
This just updates eslint types to be in sync with the last few versions.
I just went through the [history on the nodejs api docs file](https://github.com/eslint/eslint/commits/f2c2d350425268efa4b78ee6e0a2df8860e0efad/docs/developer-guide/nodejs-api.md) and compared the commits to what we have.
